message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Learning agile soccer skills for a bipedal robot with deep reinforcement learning
Paper Abstract: We investigated whether deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is able to synthesize sophisticated and safe movement skills for a low-cost, miniature humanoid robot that can be composed into complex behavioral strategies. We used deep RL to train a humanoid robot to play a simplified one-versus-one soccer game. The resulting agent exhibits robust and dynamic movement skills, such as rapid fall recovery, walking, turning, and kicking, and it transitions between them in a smooth and efficient manner. It also learned to anticipate ball movements and block opponent shots. The agent’s tactical behavior adapts to specific game contexts in a way that would be impractical to manually design. Our agent was trained in simulation and transferred to real robots zero-shot. A combination of sufficiently high-frequency control, targeted dynamics randomization, and perturbations during training enabled good-quality transfer. In experiments, the agent walked 181% faster, turned 302% faster, took 63% less time to get up, and kicked a ball 34% faster than a scripted baseline.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Reinforcement Learning Overview

I've gathered comprehensive information about Reinforcement Learning from the search results. Here's what I found:

### Core Definition

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)It is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

### Key Concepts

While supervised and unsupervised learning algorithms attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)The agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge to take the best action (exploitation).

### Applications

RL has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

### Related Subfields

The search results revealed several important subfields and techniques:

- **Deep Reinforcement Learning**: Deep reinforcement learning is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning and deep learning, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

- **Multi-Agent RL**: Multi-agent reinforcement learning is a sub-field that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

- **Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback**: RLHF is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Transfer Learning"

Links: [{"title":"Transfer learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_learning"},{"title":"Transfer of learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_of_learning"},{"title":"Negative transfer (memory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_transfer_(memory)"},{"title":"Curriculum learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curriculum_learning"},{"title":"Knowledge transfer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_transfer"},{"title":"Botetourt Medal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Botetourt_Medal"},{"title":"Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intersegmental_General_Education_Transfer_Curriculum"},{"title":"Knowledge distillation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_distillation"},{"title":"Cleveland Jackson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Jackson"},{"title":"Open Learning Institute of British Columbia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Learning_Institute_of_British_Columbia"}]

Here are the results for your search on "Transfer Learning":

## Transfer Learning in Machine Learning

Transfer learning (TL) is a technique in machine learning (ML) in which knowledge learned from a task is re-used in order to boost performance on a related task.(no content)For example, for image classification, knowledge gained while learning to recognize cars could be applied when trying to recognize trucks.

### Historical Context

In 1981, a report considered the application of transfer learning to a dataset of images representing letters of computer terminals, experimentally demonstrating positive and negative transfer learning, and in 1992, Lorien Pratt formulated the discriminability-based transfer (DBT) algorithm.(no content)Ng said in his NIPS 2016 tutorial that TL would become the next driver of machine learning commercial success after supervised learning.

### Applications

Transfer learning has been applied to cancer subtype discovery, building utilization, general game playing, text classification, digit recognition, medical imaging and spam filtering.

## Transfer of Learning (Psychology)

The search also returned information on the psychology concept of transfer of learning: Transfer of learning occurs when people apply information, strategies, and skills they have learned to a new situation or context.

### Related Concept: Knowledge Distillation

A related machine learning technique is knowledge distillation: In machine learning, knowledge distillation or model distillation is the process of transferring knowledge from a large model to a smaller one.

I've completed the web search for "Deep Reinforcement Learning." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning.(no content)RL considers the problem of a computational agent learning to make decisions by trial and error.

## How It Works

Deep RL incorporates deep learning into the solution, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.(no content)Deep RL algorithms are able to take in very large inputs (e.g. every pixel rendered to the screen in a video game) and decide what actions to perform to optimize an objective (e.g. maximizing the game score).

## Notable Achievements

In the past decade, deep RL has achieved remarkable results on a range of problems, from single and multiplayer games such as Go, Atari Games, and Dota 2 to robotics.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning reached another milestone in 2015 when AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board.

## Applications

Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

Web search results for query: "Soccer Robot"

Links: [{"title":"Soccer robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soccer_robot"},{"title":"Robot football - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_football"},{"title":"Federation of International Robot-soccer Association - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federation_of_International_Robot-soccer_Association"},{"title":"RoboCup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RoboCup"},{"title":"Category:Robot soccer competitions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Robot_soccer_competitions"},{"title":"Category:Soccer robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Soccer_robots"},{"title":"RoboCup Small Size League - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RoboCup_Small_Size_League"},{"title":"World Robot Olympiad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Robot_Olympiad"},{"title":"Cyberball - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyberball"},{"title":"RoboCup 3D Soccer Simulation League - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RoboCup_3D_Soccer_Simulation_League"}]

Here are the results for "Soccer Robot":

## Overview

A soccer robot is a specialized autonomous robot and mobile robot that is used to play variants of football.

## Major Competitions

The main organized competitions are RoboCup or FIRA tournaments played each year. 

**RoboCup:** RoboCup is an annual international robotics competition founded in 1996 by a group of university professors, and the aim is to promote robotics and AI research by offering a publicly appealing challenge.(no content)The ultimate goal is for "a team of fully autonomous humanoid robot soccer players to win a soccer game, complyingwith the official rules of FIFA, against the winner of the most recent World Cup" by the middle of the 21st century.

**FIRA:** The Federation of International Robot-soccer Association (FIRA) is an international organisation organising competitive soccer – usually 5-a-side – competitions between autonomous robots.

## League Types

Some notable leagues include:
- **Small Size League:** Two teams of six robots which are limited to an 18 cm diameter and 15 cm height play soccer with an orange golf ball.
- **3D Simulation League:** The RoboCup 3D Simulated Soccer League allows software agents to control humanoid robots to compete against one another in a realistic simulation of the rules and physics of a game of soccer.

## Youth Competitions

The World Robot Olympiad (WRO) is a global robotics competition for young people that was first held in 2004 in Singapore and now attracts more than 70,000 students from more than 95 countries.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Humanoid Robot"

Links: [{"title":"Humanoid robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_robot"},{"title":"Category:Humanoid robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Humanoid_robots"},{"title":"Sophia (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophia_(robot)"},{"title":"Humanoid Robotics Project - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_Robotics_Project"},{"title":"International Journal of Humanoid Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Journal_of_Humanoid_Robotics"},{"title":"1X Technologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1X_Technologies"},{"title":"Atlas (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlas_(robot)"},{"title":"Leju Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leju_Robot"},{"title":"Valkyrie (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valkyrie_(robot)"},{"title":"Ai-Da - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ai-Da"}]

Here's a summary of the web search results for "Humanoid Robot":

## Definition and Purpose

A humanoid robot is a robot resembling the human body in shape.(no content)The design may be aimed at functional purposes, such as interacting with human tools and environments and working alongside humans, for experimental purposes, such as the study of bipedal locomotion, or for other purposes.

## Historical Background

Humanoid robots have a long conceptual history. In the 3rd century BCE, a Taoist philosophical text called the Liezi, written by Chinese philosopher Lie Yukou, detailed the idea of a humanoid automaton, including mention of an engineer named Yan Shi who created a life-size, human-like robot for the fifth king of the Chinese Zhou Dynasty, King Mu.

## Modern Applications

Humanoid robots are now used as research tools in several scientific areas, and researchers study the human body structure and behavior (biomechanics) to build humanoid robots.(no content)Humanoid robots are being used to develop complex prosthetics for individuals with physical disabilities such as missing limbs.

## Notable Examples

Some prominent modern humanoid robots include:

- **Atlas**: The new fully electric Atlas, revealed in 2024 following the previous model's retirement, is stronger and possesses a wider range of movement in comparison to its predecessor.

- **Sophia**: The robot, modelled after the Ancient Egyptian Queen Nefertiti, Audrey Hepburn, and its inventor's wife, Amanda Hanson, is known for its human-like appearance and behaviour compared to previous robotic variants.

- **NEO**: On October 28, 2025, 1X opened pre-orders for NEO, also known as NEO Home Robot, a humanoid robot designed for use in private homes, scheduled for release in 2026.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Bipedal Robot"

Links: [{"title":"Humanoid robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_robot"},{"title":"Category:Bipedal robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Bipedal_robots"},{"title":"Category:Bipedal humanoid robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Bipedal_humanoid_robots"},{"title":"Category talk:Bipedal robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category_talk:Bipedal_robots"},{"title":"Robo One - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robo_One"},{"title":"MABEL (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MABEL_(robot)"},{"title":"Atlas (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlas_(robot)"},{"title":"Raptor (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raptor_(robot)"},{"title":"Land Walker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_Walker"},{"title":"ASIMO - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASIMO"}]

Here are the search results for "Bipedal Robot":

## Overview

A bipedal robot is a robot with two legs.(no content)The design of bipedal robots may be aimed at functional purposes, such as interacting with human tools and environments and working alongside humans, for experimental purposes, such as the study of bipedal locomotion, or for other purposes.

## Notable Bipedal Robots

Several significant bipedal robots have been developed:

- **MABEL**: MABEL is a robot engineered in 2009 by researchers at the University of Michigan, which is well known for being the world's fastest bipedal robot with knees, able to reach speeds of up to 3.6 m/s (6.8 mph).

- **Raptor**: Raptor has a top speed of 46 km/h, making it the fastest bipedal robot worldwide.

- **Atlas**: The first Atlas robot was a bipedal hydraulic humanoid robot primarily developed by Boston Dynamics with funding and oversight from the U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA).(no content)The new fully electric Atlas, revealed in 2024 following the previous model's retirement, is stronger and possesses a wider range of movement in comparison to its predecessor.

- **ASIMO**: ASIMO is a humanoid robot created by Honda in 2000.

## Competitions

Robo-One is a robot competition category of bipedal humanoid robots, with the first ROBO-ONE contest held in Japan on February 2, 2002.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Humanoid robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_robot"},{"title":"Category:Bipedal robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Bipedal_robots"},{"title":"Category:Bipedal humanoid robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Bipedal_humanoid_robots"},{"title":"Category talk:Bipedal robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category_talk:Bipedal_robots"},{"title":"Robo One - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robo_One"},{"title":"MABEL (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MABEL_(robot)"},{"title":"Atlas (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlas_(robot)"},{"title":"Raptor (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raptor_(robot)"},{"title":"Land Walker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_Walker"},{"title":"ASIMO - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASIMO"}]

Here are the search results for "Bipedal Robot":

## Overview

A bipedal robot is a robot with two legs.(no content)The design of bipedal robots may be aimed at functional purposes, such as interacting with human tools and environments and working alongside humans, for experimental purposes, such as the study of bipedal locomotion, or for other purposes.

## Notable Bipedal Robots

Several significant bipedal robots have been developed:

- **MABEL**: MABEL is a robot engineered in 2009 by researchers at the University of Michigan, which is well known for being the world's fastest bipedal robot with knees, able to reach speeds of up to 3.6 m/s (6.8 mph).

- **Raptor**: Raptor has a top speed of 46 km/h, making it the fastest bipedal robot worldwide.

- **Atlas**: The first Atlas robot was a bipedal hydraulic humanoid robot primarily developed by Boston Dynamics with funding and oversight from the U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA).(no content)The new fully electric Atlas, revealed in 2024 following the previous model's retirement, is stronger and possesses a wider range of movement in comparison to its predecessor.

- **ASIMO**: ASIMO is a humanoid robot created by Honda in 2000.

## Competitions

Robo-One is a robot competition category of bipedal humanoid robots, with the first ROBO-ONE contest held in Japan on February 2, 2002.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Learning agile soccer skills for a bipedal robot with deep reinforcement learning". Here's a summary of what was done:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Extracted Triples (5 entities):**

1. **Deep reinforcement learning** (method/uses) - The core technique combining reinforcement learning with deep learning to train the robot movement skills.

2. **Humanoid robot** (artifact/uses) - The type of bipedal robot platform used to perform soccer skills and movement tasks.

3. **Soccer robot** (task/proposes) - The novel application of training a humanoid robot to play one-versus-one soccer with sophisticated behavioral strategies.

4. **Reinforcement learning** (method/uses) - The foundational machine learning paradigm for training agents through interactions with their environment.

5. **Transfer learning** (method/proposes) - The zero-shot sim-to-real transfer technique enabling knowledge from simulation to transfer to real robots.
